title: Wednesday, 20th December, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE11:03am

Hey. Good morning. Welcome to Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily thing with the markets and the live.

Soundbuy Morning
Blank canvas good morning everyone
Boncoeur Good morning
SupposeToBeWorking... Morning
BE11:03am

Quite a bit going on this morning, even if there's very few people around to watch it.

BE11:04am

Head counts falling, volume not great.

Mouselet Good morning all
AAAA bonjour !
11:05 am
BE11:05am

Though, having said that, volume looked pretty lively in Shire ADRs overnight.

BE11:05am

Mouselet Whose counted heads are falling?
BE11:06am

That's a 6% move at the peak, after various market reports noted fresh grift around Shire.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

Now, there is a specific story here. Which I'll get to in a moment.

BE11:06am

First, though, have a downgrade.

BE11:07am

Here's Liberum.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

We upgraded Shire in mid November on the grounds that the valuation was simply too compelling to ignore with all the key risks finally more than priced in. Since then, despite better than expected competitor hemophilia data and a small pipeline failure yesterday, the shares are up over 14% in dollar terms. Adjusting for this failure (SHP609, c.-1%) and FX moves (c.-1%), we trim our valuation to £41/share which now implies just 4.5% upside. We still believe that, if handled right, the update on the neuroscience strategic review due by year end could be a catalyst for the shares, but with fundamental upside now limited the risk/reward is more balanced. Downgrade to Hold.

BornCynic Good morning - I hate shares.
BornCynic Drax on 12th Dec - everything is fine here
BE11:07am

And spinning down to the neuroscience stuff .......

BE11:08am

When we upgraded Shire in mid-November, it traded at an almost 20% discount to NPV which we believed reflected, at least in part, perceived M&A risk as the company de-levers into a big earnings hole in the early 2020s. We thought that the announced strategic review of the neuroscience business could mitigate this M&A risk if handled sensibly - for example by spinning out neuroscience with a meaningful portion of the debt and then re-focusing the remaining business on cash returns (e.g. via buybacks).

Boncoeur @BornCynic, you should watch the bond market then, use binds to tell you when to get in and out of a ftse100 etf
Mouselet Drax is presumably one of the few places where 'everything is on fire' is an important and expected part of the performance metric
11:08 am
BE11:08am

However, ahead of the pending year end update on the strategic review, the discount has to a large extent already been closed. In addition, there is of course a risk that the outcome of the review is not the one we favour and that this disappoints the market.

Bid speculation may help the shares; chance of a take-out incrementally increases with neuroscience spinout but remains low probability in our view.

BornCynic Drax today - problem unloading wood pellets, sorry, but it looks like the bloke with the spanner and hammer is not going to be able to fix it and it will be a £10 million hit..
BornCynic My New Years resolution - sell everything and buy Apple :)
Boncoeur Buy swda.ln
Flaneur EC ruling on Uber looks to finally be muzzling the Tech giants - Goofacetwit as a publisher? AirBnB as a hotel group?
BE11:11am

Okay ......

Soundbuy @BornCynic - really bad yr and that would read 'buy an apple'
BE11:12am

... oh, sorry, one last par.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Beyond helping dissipate an M&A discount that has now mostly unwound anyway, a neuroscience spinout could also prompt further bid speculation in respect of the remaining Shire business.

BE11:12am

Big pharma has long disliked ADHD as a therapeutic area (and we believe feared dis-synergies from running such a business) yet might find a rare disease pure play more appealing.

BE11:12am

However, we would caution that such a deal would likely deliver limited S&M synergies given the rare disease focus, leaving central cost savings as the key to an acquirer creating value. Given we do not believe the shares trade at a significant discount to fair value, we believe almost all the benefit from such synergies would need to be given up to justify a c.25% premium / £50 valuation. In any case, we are simply unwilling to remain buyers of this (or any) stock on the purely speculative grounds there could be a takeout.

A. M. @Flaneur: about time, too. What is an 'information society service'?
11:13 am
BE11:13am

... right, so that's why Shire's not a credible bid target.

Mouselet Something like an email provider?
BE11:13am

Now for the explanation why it was up nearly 7% overnight.

BE11:13am

The idea in the market is that Pfizer is interested.

BornCynic @Soundbuy - I think the world and his dog have bought Apple on the same principle - a crowded trade.......
11:13 am
BE11:14am

As in, Pfizer is interested enough to have made an approach.

chopper bear £51 floating around
A. M. @Mouselet: fair enough. Don't see how uber can use that as a fig-leaf, though.
Boncoeur #uber: We need to delineate between employed and self employed better. Imho, if you bring capital to the party you're a business.
Mouselet "we will sell 20% of everyone in the Western world, with a bias towards the rich, a thing that costs a week's income every other year" is not the worst business to be in
BE11:14am

And a preliminary offer somewhere just below the £50 a share mark.

Mouselet So a man with a van is a business?
BE11:15am

(@Chopper: that's what we call "made up".)

chopper bear lol @be
11:15 am
BE11:15am

This is, to be clear, RAW.

Boncoeur @mouselet: yes, the van is a capital item
BE11:15am

Though we've tested it through several channels.

A. M. @Mouselet: well, if a man+van transfers goods/people and expects payment for this, then I guess yes.
BE11:16am

And people we'd expect to be familiar with the situation have been unequivocal that nothing's happening.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

As in, there have been no discussions whatsoever and there's absolutely no truth in the theory.

Mouselet but that's the absolutely archetypal self-employment case, no?
BE11:16am

You also have the problem of timing, namely Christmas.

BE11:16am

Offices are shutting down from this week. Anything happening now would be rather disruptive to quite a few holidays.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

There's also the problem of tax reform.

Mouselet isn't holiday disruption what junior partners at M&A consultancies are *for*?
BE11:16am

Why would Pfizer be in talks to buy an Irish-domiciled company when the tax implications are unknown? Dunno.

A. M. @Mouselet: well, had it been a collection of persons+vans, then maybe. But it has been shown that it's not quite the case.
Boncoeur @mouselet: self employed is code for neing in business on your own account, you just get lower nics rate
Forester Looked closely at Drax - they are burning wood pellets that have been felled in inland USA, hauled by trucks to ports then shipped 5,000 miles in bunker fuel burning ships to UK then hauled again to Drax to be burnt as an environmentally friendly source of power! Madness.
Mouselet Probably more environmentally friendly than doing the same thing with coal
Mouselet (I don't think you transfer coal from the Powder River Basin in the middle to the coasts by pipeline)
BE11:18am

I guess we should also, if only out of politeness, note that the Panel should be forcing companies to make statements when their shares move a lot and there's a rumour in the market that's true. Therefore, the lack of a statement might indicate that no statement is required.

BornCynic @Mouselet - a good point
A. M. (by the way, wasn't that argument put forward by fedex? despite the livery etc., that its drivers are actually self-employed)
Mouselet and IIRC shipping in really big ships is something like 1% the CO2 per ton-mile of driving a Ford Fiesta
11:18 am
BE11:19am

I say might because .... well, you know. The Panel moves in mysterious ways that aren't always entirely transparent.

Forester @mousalet would be interest to do comparison with using British coal and burning at Drax with filters fitted.
BE11:19am

Anyway.

Mouselet (driving to the depot to pick up an Amazon delivery is a worst payload-to-mass ratio than the Pluto probe)
Boncoeur A.M.: Fedex is right, if the drivers are bringing their own vehivke then they have their own business and should not go off cying to the courts for holiday pay, sick pay etc.
Boncoeur Vehicle
BE11:20am

Pfizer-Shire is the rumour. And now it's in the public domain, perhaps someone will respond to it in a useful way.

11:19 am
BE11:20am

Fingers crossed.

undefined
wayneJ For a US co that has petitioned to have lower taxes so it can repatriate overseas cash to then use that cash for an acquisition overseas might tempt the wrath of shareholders.
BE11:20am

I bring you £50bn M&A rumours, rabble, and you talk to me about woodchips.

11:20 am
Drax Group PLC (DRX:LSE): Last: 263.30, down 13.1 (-4.74%), High: 269.40, Low: 252.20, Volume: 717.11k
A. M. @Boncoeur: I do believe fedex required them to purchase said vehicles, but I might be mistaken. It was not a "how about I make some $$ by driving for fedex on my off-hours"

wayneJ Also worth noting that UK companies disappointing are frequently the subject of 'bid rumours' - one might speculate that this is convenient for those who are wrong and long.
Boncoeur A.M.: ok
BE11:21am

Biomass in short supply because of an unplanned outage on rail-unloading facilities, which I think means a loading bay's borked.

Lemmy The Panel *should* but it doesn't always do this of late. Think they've done recent consultations on this matter to try and pin this down a bit more
urgeview If Pfizer take out Shp. I'll take you to Core
BornCynic As I said BE - Keith, the bloke with the spanner and hammer, can't fix this one.............
BE11:22am

(@wayneJ: you surely know we're a filtering system here. Long and wrong doesn't get a lot of airtime.)

Penderyn The chips are down
wayneJ At a time that the UK is short gas - any idea what is happening to spot wholesale electricity prices? Is it going to be a white Christmas?
Boncoeur The teade unions cheered when uber drivers got holiday pay, that should tell you enough
11:23 am
BE11:23am

Here's Barclays to put it into context.

BE11:23am

Drax has announced that an unplanned outage on a conveyor delivering fuel from their biomass rail unloading facilities (which first occurred last Friday) will cut 2017 EBITDA by around £10mn, with the company now guiding to c.£220mn. As a result of the outage Drax has been running its 2 ROC biomass units at lower load factor due to the reduction in biomass fuel delivery capacity, and will shortly take them offline entirely to complete repairs. Drax will prioritise biomass fuel deliveries to the higher margin CfD subsidised biomass unit which should continue to run at normal levels, whilst the coal units are unaffected. Drax currently expects the repairs to be completed by mid January 2018; if they return to service at this time then 2018 EBITDA is likely to be cut by £10-15mn to around £250mn (based on current Bloomberg consensus). Drax stated that the capital cost of repairs is minimal. There are no problems with any of the biomass generation units themselves.

BE11:23am

Whilst all generation plants experience unplanned outages, Drax’s biomass units are very profitable – especially during winter months – and this means group earnings have significant exposure to even relatively brief unplanned outages on these units. We expect today’s announcement to have a negative impact on the shares, though at this stage we do not expect a material long term impact on our investment thesis, and expect that strong cash generation will allow the payment of significant ongoing special dividends from next year. That said, the capacity for special dividends in 2018 could easily be reduced vs our current forecast of £75mn all else equal due to this outage.

A. M. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-fedex-settlement/fedex-to-settle-driver-lawsuits-in-20-states-for-240-million-idUSKCN0Z229Q
11:23 am
BE11:24am

Drax was of course marked as one of the beneficiaries of the Forties pipeline breaking

wayneJ @BE - agreed - and you highlight that 'people ....familiar....are unequivocal that nothing's happening' - I was alluding to the general propensity of certain UK press to pick up such rumours - especially at convenient times for people who are long eg year end, quarter end etc....
BE11:24am

As it lift the price of marginal, infill supply.

BE11:25am

A £10m hit isn't that useful in that context.

A. M. @BE: isn't Drax a baseload supplier?
11:25 am
BE11:25am

Credit Suisse .....

BE11:25am

To recall, biomass supply chains are much tighter than thermal coal. The material is more bulky and cannot easily be stored as it could combust or degrade more easily. Hence biomass-fired production is more susceptible to outages on the supply chain. The closer outages are to the units, the more difficult they are to mitigate. Stopping generation may mean expensive power buybacks as well, which can compound issues.

BE11:26am

We understand that some of the conveyors specific to the new rail unloading facility. We understand there was small localised fire last Friday and the solution to restore the assets is being put in place. ROC ssets have been ramped-down overnight already, hence there is some impact. Coal and the CfD units are unaffected.

pancakes or waffles hello all
Boncoeur @A.M.: ok, if Fedex insist upon a log that renders the capital item, the van, unusable for other companies, so that was wrong of them
Boncoeur Logo
11:26 am
BE11:26am

REMIT data shows the outage on unit 2 and 3 starting this morning and continuing until 15 January. The units will be turned down on Friday. Each biomass-fired unit earns c£8m per month EBITDA. Power market buy-backs will increase this, as the power curve has increased (c£60-75/MWh in the balancing market, versus hedged costs of c£46/MWh).

wayneJ UK ICE Daily UK Electricity Baseload at 56.48 GBP/MWh as of yesterday?
BE11:26am

We would assume an approximate doubling of the cost to c£16m per unit. A four-week outage on two units would cost c£30m, of which c£10m would be in 2017E and c£20m in 2018E. The major risk from hereon would be if there were a ‘squeeze’ in power because the system has lost c1.3GW of generation, albeit we expect lower demand going into the holiday season.

BE11:27am

Action
While unwelcome and one-off in nature, it flags the risk to Drax as it is an asset where all the profitability is focused upon three biomass-fired units and a supply business. We value Drax on a DCF/EVA® valuation, which arrives at our 370p/share TP. This includes the coal-fired generation on a negative c£634m valuation (-155p/share). The stock trades on c5.0x 2018E EV/EBITDA, whereas we value Drax on 7.2x

A. M. @Boncoeur: as the article states, they have since got clever, and increased the level of separation from the drivers (same as ryanair's practices with the pilots, I suppose)
Boncoeur A.M.: I can't imagine pilots bringing their own plane to the party, pilots are employees.
BornCynic That's the problem - it has shown Drax to be fragile and will have increased the risk of holding the shares........
11:28 am
BE11:28am

And RBC as well.

BE11:28am

At present the newer rail unloading facilities are offline, whilst Drax is using older facilities to fuel the more profitable CfD unit. If required Drax could also receive limited fuel supplies via road. The £10m expected reduction in 2017 EBITDA represents a ~4% reduction in our forecast 2017E EBITDA of £233m which is in line with consensus. Per our discussion with the company, the current plan is to return the units on 15th January and if the proposed return date is met then the impact would be ~£10-15m for 2018E, which would be a ~4% impact on our 2018E EBITDA estimate of £275m (versus consensus at ~£260m).

BE11:28am

Please tell me that's enough on woodchips.

11:28 am
undefined

wayneJ Surely the key for Drax is to invite all middle aged men in the area to spend Christmas building their own log fires to feed the generators.....
Stateless @wayneJ - not a daft question. Answer (I think) is...depends on what the trade negotiators come up with.
A. M. @Boncoeur: re pilots -- the story was that ryanair instructed them to form their own companies, etc.

BE11:30am

Okay.

Boncoeur @A.M.: and that was wrong, I am layong down a principle here, businesses bring capital to the party.
BE11:31am

I'll put my phone onto mute so we can plough on with the next half hour.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

There's Mondi ......

Mondi PLC (MNDI:LSE): Last: 1,889, up 62 (+3.39%), High: 1,890, Low: 1,840, Volume: 812.56k
wayneJ @Stateless - interesting - can imagine if Europe is under heavy snow the EU prioritises gas deliveries from storage for EU members; ditto re electricity. Clearly not thought through.
BE11:32am

.... which is on a Goldman upgrade.

phil5 @Boncoeur - so Ryanair cabin crew who have to buy their own uniform are bringing capital to the business?
wayneJ Mondi = paper and packaging - another part of the woodchip business.
Boncoeur @phil5: too trivial an expense
11:33 am
BE11:33am

Which is part of a bigger thing about inflecting pulp prices. As in, inflecting lower.

BE11:33am

The idea here is that Mondi's cheap.

phil5 @Boncoeur so one would need a non-trivial amount test
wayneJ Incidentally has anyone bought a wood/log burning fire from ebay
Mouselet that strikes me as a recipe for free carbon monoxide incidents
BE11:34am

We upgrade Mondi to Buy (from Neutral) with a 12-month price target of 2,200p (18% upside). Since the 3Q earnings release on October 11, the stock is down 11%, underperforming our coverage by 21% and offering an attractive entry opportunity. Mondi remains the highest-return company in our coverage; recent containerboard price increases are a tailwind for 2018 earnings, as are annual contracts resetting at higher levels. In addition, we expect ongoing capex projects to underpin growth from 2019. Our base dividend forecast implies a 3% yield for 2017 which we believe could be more than doubled through a potential special dividend announcement at the FY results.

Boncoeur @Phil:There would need to be a threshold, tax systems have lots of thresholds
11:34 am
BE11:34am

We identify the following key catalysts: (1) news of announced containerboard increases being achieved, along with annual contracts resetting at higher levels for most divisions; (2) positive demand data for containerboard/box shipments announced monthly; and (3) the potential announcement of a special dividend at the FY results, as per company comments.

A. M. @wayneJ: gas storage is a fairly local thing (I would expect). Also, there's not that much of it.
BE11:35am

Wasn't there containerboard price hikes last week? As in, Thursday?

A. M. (http://www.gie.eu/index.php/maps-data/gse-storage-map)
BE11:35am

SKG, Mondi both raised prices, right?

Soundbuy Yep , smurfit price increases from 8th Jan IIRC
11:35 am
BE11:36am

Have Goldman on the sector view as well.

BE11:36am

The pulp rally was, in our view, driven by significant supply disruptions and a restock in the China paper and board market, which increased demand, especially in the first half. We expect disrupted production to come back to the market in 2018; this, combined with new additions ramping up, should move the market back into oversupply and drive prices down from current peak levels, leading to relative underperformance of pulp-exposed stocks.

Soundbuy https://www.euwid-paper.com/news/singlenews/Artikel/smurfit-kappa-to-hike-prices-for-all-containerboard-grades.html
Soundbuy 15th Jan.........
BE11:37am

It's a bit of a "short and wrong, double down" call from Goldman.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

We have been bearish on pulp prices throughout 2017 given our expectation of new, capacity coming online, pushing the market into oversupply. However, pulp prices have risen throughout this year, driven by: (1) supply disruptions and delays to
ramp-ups, which caused unforeseen tightness in the market; (2) unexpectedly strong demand, supported in part by the Chinese restocking and recent clampdown on Recovered Paper (RCP) imports, which led to producers rotating into pulp to satisfy their fibre needs; and (3) a weak US dollar, which also acted as a tailwind for prices.

BE11:37am

Pulp has been the best performing commodity this year.

BE11:38am

........ (apart from Cryptokitties) ......

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Prices have rallied strongly, reaching historic peaks, with hardwood pulp up 49% ytd and softwood up 23% ytd (FOEX pricing), setting the stage for a pulp price correction, in our view. We expect prices to remain at their record highs in the near term, until delayed/disrupted
production returns to the market. In 1Q18, we expect pulp prices to decline in line with the normalisation of production, although we see lower downside than we previously predicted, as medium-term supply/demand looks more balanced. The normalisation of production should lead to c.1.5 mnt of disrupted production coming back online, easing the current tightness. Demand already shows signs of a slowdown: according to PPPC data, pulp shipments are down 11%/7% mom in China/globally for October 2017
.

BE11:38am

That's the theme anyway.

Smurfit Kappa Group PLC (SKG:LSE): Last: 2,445, up 3 (+0.12%), High: 2,457, Low: 2,430, Volume: 41.27k

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Real interest rates are deeply negative providing a backstop for the equity
market. Equally, money supply is stable and the weak exchange rate is providing a boost to competitiveness. At the same time as the household sector and consumption is experiencing a challenging environment, the business sector’s animal spirits are beginning to rise. After a year of strong PMI numbers and better export data, companies are facing the prospect of capacity constraints.

A. M. @waynej: is that inclusive of the cushion gas?
BE11:44am

Just as there is a bi-polar environment for the economy, the same is true for the equity market. On the one hand, the balance of payments is deteriorating with foreign investment flows poor and the current account deficit high at -5% of GDP. Given the Brexit ongoing negotiations it is an unstable environment for investment flows. However, on the other hand, there is a growing and wide population of stocks offering value, growth and quality at attractive valuations.

Flaneur We should really look back on the 2017 previews - perhaps a theme for the final show?
wayneJ Hasn't another bitcoin exchange got robbed overnight
BornCynic BE - please don't tell me that an analyst is comparing the market to fudge?
BE11:44am

While the UK’s 2017 EPS growth of around 5% y-y was poor in comparison to most foreign bourses and 2018’s number of circa 6% is not too dramatic either versus the peer group, there seem to be a number of turning points that appear to have been quietly forgotten. Firstly, after a period in which dividend per share growth contracted, companies are expecting a modest pick-up in dividend growth as FCF is set to improve. Secondly and most impressively the ROE for the FTSE 100 companies (ex-financials) improved sharply in 2017 helped by higher asset turnover and better margins.

alewis2005 @WayneJ yep one in South Korea
11:44 am
BE11:45am

As central banks begin to move away from monetary easing to tightening
and the global economy shifts from disinflation to inflation, it is unlikely
that UK equity volatility can remain rooted so low in 2018. In this respect, it is worth watching the rolling correlation between UK equities and UK gilts since the positive correlation is likely to turn negative next year.

BE11:45am

I should explain that the note here is called "UK: a Great British sticky fudge" ....

BornCynic @Flaneur - from last years FT:Looking ahead to 2017, our experts argue a new investment phase has begun as the yield curve finally turns upwards. Flattened by years of ultra-low interest rates and monetary stimulus, world economies are gradually being weaned off quantitative easing.
11:49 am
BE11:49am

We remain bullish on Europe with monetary conditions relaxed and an ECB still hesitant to unduly tighten. Equity investors will be looking for signs of a self-sustaining recovery given strong sentiment and confidence indicators and the spectre of deflation vanquished. To this end, wage growth and investment spending are key. However, Europe is not a homogeneous set of economies - some are overheating, others still simmering. Investors need to be selective.

wayneJ @GBKrona - that link encourages one to download an EU app; surely some mistake - why isn't the EU keeping everything secret and reacted like the UK is?
A. M. @wayneJ: yes, I've went through them. The company is apparently run by the Stieg.
BE11:50am

I'd very much like to see someone feed a bunch of annual previews into a machine-learning thingmy and see what emerges.
